rpjmn_water_comprehensive_analysis.html.title: RPJMN_Water_Comprehensive_Analysis
rpjmn_water_comprehensive_analysis.html.description:
Author: Mohamad Mova AlAfghani Powered by: Claude Multi-Agent Orchestration Date: October 29, 2025 Document Type: Policy Analysis Source: RPJMN 2025-2029 (National Medium-Term Development Plan)Indonesia's National Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJMN) 2025-2029 positions water self-sufficiency (swasembada air) as a foundational pillar of national development, integrating water security across eight national priorities. This comprehensive analysis reveals a transformative approach to water governance, infrastructure development, and climate adaptation, underpinned by major institutional reforms including the establishment of an independent Water and Sanitation Regulatory Body.Water Crisis Indicators: Only 4.77% of villages have safe sanitation access Only 18.9% of villages have safe drinking water access 70% of household water sources are contaminated (2022 data) 56.1% of population (Java) has access to only 6.3% of water resources 23 million coastal residents face annual flooding by 2050 12.7 million hectares of critical land lost water regulation function Transformative Targets (2025-2029): Urban piped water access: 24% → 51.36% (114% increase) Safe sanitation access: 10.21% → 30% (194% increase) Water Quality Index: 54.59 → 72.77 (33% improvement) National Water Security Index: 3.48 → 3.75 Major Institutional Reform: Creation of independent Water and Sanitation Regulatory Body (Badan Regulator Air Minum dan Sanitasi) with operational and financial independence Full value chain coverage: raw water → drinking water → wastewater treatment Four main functions: benchmarking, tariff recommendations, quality monitoring, transparency enhancement Strategic Framework: Water Self-Sufficiency and FEW Nexus 1.1 Water as Foundation of National Self-Reliance 1.2 Food-Energy-Water (FEW) Nexus Approach 1.3 Source-to-Sea Integrated Management 1.4 Smart Water Management and Water Accounting 1.5 Water Information Systems and Data Management 1.6 National Water Security Targets (2025-2029)
Major Institutional Reform: Water and Sanitation Regulatory Body 2.1 Establishment of Independent Regulatory Authority 2.2 Four Main Regulatory Functions 2.3 Institutional Characteristics 2.4 Incentive and Disincentive Mechanisms 2.5 Restructuring of Wastewater Governance
Water Infrastructure Development Strategy 3.1 Water in National Infrastructure Priority 3.2 Three Core Water Infrastructure Programs (KPU) 3.3 National Strategic Water Projects 3.4 Nature-Based Solutions Integration 3.5 Financing Mechanisms 3.6 Lake Management and Blue Economy Integration ⭐ 3.6.1 Lake Water Quality Management Program 3.6.2 Lake Toba Strategic Tourism Development 3.6.3 Lakes in Blue Economy and Aquatic Food Systems 3.6.4 Lake Ecosystem Conservation and Carrying Capacity 3.6.5 Lake Management Challenges and Opportunities
Climate-Resilient Water Management
Rural Water Access and Village Development
Water Resources Baseline and Challenges
Key National Priorities and Linkages
Implementation Framework
Existing Regulatory Architecture
Recommendations and Conclusion Source: Priority 2 - National Self-Sufficiency (Swasembada Pangan, Energi, Air)Verbatim (Indonesian): "Dalam kemandirian bangsa, Indonesia perlu fokus pada pencapaian swasembada dalam berbagai sektor krusial yang mencakup sektor pangan sebagai pilar kehidupan bangsa; sektor energi sebagai pendorong inovasi dan kemajuan; dan sektor air sebagai fondasi kehidupan yang berkelanjutan." Translation: "In national self-reliance, Indonesia needs to focus on achieving self-sufficiency in various crucial sectors including the food sector as the pillar of national life; the energy sector as a driver of innovation and progress; and the water sector as the foundation of sustainable life." Strategic Positioning: Water is distinguished as the foundational sector (fondasi) for sustainable development, differentiating it from food (pillar) and energy (driver). This elevates water to the highest strategic significance.Related Notes:
Water Conflict in Indonesia - Understanding water allocation conflicts
Kekuatan dan Keterbatasan dari '6 Prinsip Dasar' Mahkamah Konstitusi Indonesia dalam Menyelesaikan Konflik Air - Legal framework for water conflict resolution
Perbedaan Fitur Regulasi Sumber Daya Air dengan Pelayanan Air - Dual regulatory framework Verbatim (Indonesian): "Swasembada air menjadi salah satu penerapan pendekatan Food, Energi, Water Nexus dalam rangka mewujudkan kemandirian bangsa terkait pemenuhan kebutuhan air berkelanjutan." Translation: "Water self-sufficiency is one application of the Food, Energy, Water Nexus approach to realize national self-reliance related to sustainable water needs fulfillment." Integration Framework: Indonesia explicitly adopts FEW Nexus as operational framework, recognizing: Water enables agricultural production (food security) Water generates renewable energy (hydropower) Agriculture requires water and energy inputs Energy powers water pumping and treatment Climate change affects all three sectors simultaneously Verbatim (Indonesian): "Upaya mewujudkan swasembada air dilaksanakan secara terintegrasi dari hulu ke hilir dengan konsep source to sea melalui penyelamatan mata air kritis; konservasi dan pengelolaan air tanah; konservasi daerah tangkapan air melalui rehabilitasi hutan dan lahan; pembangunan tampungan air untuk pemanfaatan pertanian, peternakan, air minum, dan energi terbarukan; penyediaan pasokan air berkelanjutan." Translation: "Efforts to realize water self-sufficiency are implemented in an integrated manner from upstream to downstream with a source to sea concept through: rescue of critical springs; conservation and groundwater management; watershed conservation through forest and land rehabilitation; construction of water reservoirs for agricultural, livestock, drinking water, and renewable energy utilization; provision of sustainable water supply." Key Components: Upstream: Critical spring rescue, forest rehabilitation, watershed conservation Midstream: Reservoir construction, water allocation across sectors Downstream: Sustainable supply provision, wastewater treatment, coastal protection
Related Note: Terminologi terkait Rencana Pengamanan Air - Water safety planning terminologyVerbatim (Indonesian): "Penerapan smart water management dan prinsip water accounting untuk menjaga neraca air pada tingkat wilayah sungai tidak dalam kondisi defisit/kritis/tertekan." Translation: "Implementation of smart water management and water accounting principles to maintain water balance at the river basin level not in deficit/critical/stressed conditions." Technology Integration: Digital monitoring and control systems River basin-level water balance tracking Real-time deficit prevention Integration with 105 built dams for optimization
Related Note: Water Quality Parameters -- Monitoring and Maintaining the Health of Our Waterways - Monitoring frameworksSource: Priority 2 - Badan Regulator FunctionsData Transparency and Information Systems:Verbatim (Indonesian): "peningkatan transparansi melalui pelaporan publik dan pengelolaan data" Translation: "transparency enhancement through public reporting and data management" Water Information System Components: Benchmarking System Service performance assessment across SPAM operators Comparative performance metrics Best practice identification and dissemination Public Reporting Platform Transparent service quality data Tariff information and justifications Consumer complaint tracking Infrastructure investment reporting Water Accounting Database River basin water balance monitoring Real-time water availability tracking Demand-supply matching Deficit/stress early warning system Integrated Social-Economic Registration System (Sistem Registrasi Sosial Ekonomi) Targeting water/sanitation beneficiaries Poverty and vulnerability data integration Subsidy and assistance delivery tracking SEPAKAT System (Village-Level Data) Sistem Perencanaan Pembangunan Berbasis Data Regsosek Terpadu Village-level water infrastructure needs assessment Dana Desa allocation planning Progress monitoring for rural water projects Digital Transformation in Water Sector:Verbatim (Indonesian): "era digitalisasi mengharuskan ekonomi digital menjadi akselerasi peningkatan daya saing" Translation: "the digitalization era requires digital economy to accelerate competitiveness enhancement" Priority Activities Supporting Water Information Systems: KPU #28: Pengembangan dan Peningkatan Ekosistem Digital (Development and Enhancement of Digital Ecosystem) KPU #78: Transformasi Digital Layanan Publik (Digital Transformation of Public Services) Water Data Governance Principles: Integrated planning - Unified data infrastructure across agencies Transparency - Public access to water service performance data Evidence-based decision making - Data-driven policy formulation Accountability - Performance tracking and reporting mechanisms Related Notes:
Tantangan Regulasi Pelayanan Air di Indonesia - Current data and monitoring gaps
Terminologi terkait Rencana Pengamanan Air - Water safety monitoring terminology Analysis: Most ambitious: Safe sanitation access (194% increase) and urban piped water (114% increase) Quality focus: Major water quality improvement (33% increase) addressing 70% contamination crisis Infrastructure-intensive: All targets require massive capital investment
Related Note: Standar kualitas air minum - Drinking water quality standardsTHIS IS A TRANSFORMATIVE GOVERNANCE REFORMVerbatim (Indonesian): "Pembentukan Badan Regulator Air Minum dan Sanitasi memperkuat fungsi pengaturan, pengawasan, dan advisori yang selama ini terfragmentasi dan belum berjalan optimal, sekaligus menjadi langkah debottlenecking untuk menciptakan tata kelola lebih efektif dan efisien. Sejalan dengan visi swasembada air, badan ini dirancang memiliki independensi operasional serta finansial untuk memastikan ketersediaan air yang berkeadilan dan berkelanjutan bagi seluruh rakyat Indonesia, mencakup pengelolaan terpadu dari hulu ke hilir mulai dari penyediaan air baku, penyediaan dan distribusi air minum, hingga pengolahan air limbah domestik." Translation: "The establishment of the Water and Sanitation Regulatory Body strengthens regulatory, supervisory, and advisory functions that have been fragmented and not running optimally, while becoming a debottlenecking step to create more effective and efficient governance. In line with the vision of water self-sufficiency, this body is designed to have operational and financial independence to ensure equitable and sustainable water availability for all Indonesian people, covering integrated management from upstream to downstream starting from raw water supply, drinking water supply and distribution, to domestic wastewater treatment." Verbatim (Indonesian): "Badan ini memiliki peran utama yaitu: Penilaian kinerja layanan melalui sistem benchmarking Pemberian rekomendasi tarif dan retribusi berbasis prinsip keadilan, efisiensi ekonomi, model pemulihan biaya, dan keterjangkauan Pemantauan terhadap standar kuantitas dan kualitas layanan Peningkatan transparansi melalui pelaporan publik dan pengelolaan data" Translation - Four Main Roles: Service performance assessment through benchmarking system Tariff and retribution recommendations based on principles of equity, economic efficiency, cost recovery model, and affordability Monitoring of service quantity and quality standards Transparency enhancement through public reporting and data management
Related Note: Tantangan Regulasi Pelayanan Air di Indonesia - Current regulatory challengesKey Features: Independent - Operational and financial independence from government line agencies Comprehensive scope - Full value chain: raw water → drinking water → wastewater Source-to-sea integration - Aligns with integrated water management approach Debottlenecking role - Addresses current fragmented governance structure Equity-focused - Mandate to ensure "berkeadilan" (equitable/just) water availability Comparison with Current Fragmentation: Before: Regulatory functions scattered across Ministry of Public Works, Ministry of Health, Ministry of Environment, local governments After: Unified regulatory authority with clear mandate and independence Verbatim (Indonesian): "Untuk mendukung peningkatan layanan, badan ini menjalankan mekanisme insentif dan disinsentif yang diharapkan dapat memacu kinerja operator, efisiensi biaya, dan optimalisasi sumber daya." Translation: "To support service improvement, this body will run incentive and disincentive mechanisms that are expected to spur operator performance, cost efficiency, and resource optimization." Performance-Based Regulation: Tied to service quality and quantity standards Targets operator efficiency and resource optimization Balances consumer protection with provider viability
Related Note: Perbedaan Fitur Regulasi Sumber Daya Air dengan Pelayanan Air - Distinguishing water resources from water services regulationVerbatim (Indonesian): "Penataan Kewenangan Penyelenggaraan Urusan Air Limbah Domestik... bertujuan untuk menciptakan pembagian peran dan tanggung jawab yang lebih jelas antara pemerintah pusat, provinsi, dan kabupaten/kota dalam penyelenggaraan layanan air limbah domestik." Translation: "Restructuring of Domestic Wastewater Service Authority... aims to create clearer division of roles and responsibilities between central government, provinces, and districts/cities in providing domestic wastewater services." Multi-Level Coordination: Central government - Policy and standards setting Provincial government - Oversight and support to struggling districts District/city government - Operational service delivery (UPTD, BLUD, BUMD, PDAM) Provincial Role Strengthening: "Provinsi akan menjalankan fungsi pengawasan untuk memastikan kinerja layanan di tingkat kabupaten/kota sesuai dengan standar yang telah ditetapkan. Provinsi juga diberikan kewenangan lebih untuk ikut serta dalam menyediakan layanan air limbah domestik pada kabupaten/kotanya yang kesulitan." Translation: "Provinces will carry out supervisory functions to ensure service performance at district/city level meets established standards. Provinces are also given greater authority to participate in providing domestic wastewater services to districts/cities that have difficulty." Source: Priority 3 - Infrastructure Development and Quality EmploymentVerbatim (Indonesian): "pembangunan akan mencakup penyediaan air, pembangunan rumah dan kawasan infrastruktur permukiman, pengelolaan sanitasi dan sumber pembiayaan bagi pembangunan." Translation: "development will include water supply, housing and settlement infrastructure development, sanitation management and financing sources for development." Infrastructure Stock Target:Water infrastructure contributes to this 5.5 percentage point increase.Kegiatan Prioritas Utama (Priority Activities):KPU #14: Konservasi Sumber Daya Air (Water Resource Conservation) Watershed management and protection Groundwater conservation Critical spring rescue operations Forest and land rehabilitation KPU #15: Pengembangan SPAM Terintegrasi Hulu ke Hilir SPAM = Sistem Penyediaan Air Minum (Drinking Water Supply System) Integrated approach from source to tap Full upstream-downstream coverage Primary drinking water infrastructure program KPU #16: Penyediaan dan Pengawasan Sanitasi Aman, Berkelanjutan, dan Berketahanan Iklim Berbasis CWIS CWIS = City-Wide Inclusive Sanitation (international best practice) Safe (aman), sustainable (berkelanjutan), climate-resilient (berketahanan iklim) Covers on-site and off-site sanitation Fecal sludge management (IPLT) and wastewater treatment (IPAL) Related Notes:
Singkatan dan Akronim terkait Air Minum, Sanitasi, dan Hygiene - WASH sector acronyms
Terminologi terkait Rencana Pengamanan Air - Water safety planning Seven Water Infrastructure Projects (Proyek Strategis Nasional):Strategic Distribution: 4 new dams in water-scarce regions (Maluku, NTT, Gorontalo, Central Java) 2 regional SPAM systems demonstrating economies of scale 1 giant sea wall protecting drinking water sources from saltwater intrusion Verbatim (Indonesian): "Pembangunan infrastruktur akan mengoptimalkan infrastruktur terpadu dengan memperhatikan pendekatan solusi berbasis alam untuk mengurangi risiko bencana dan perubahan iklim, sekaligus menjaga kesinambungan pembangunan dalam jangka panjang." Translation: "Infrastructure development will optimize integrated infrastructure while considering nature-based solutions approaches to reduce disaster risk and climate change while maintaining long-term development sustainability." NbS Applications in Water Infrastructure: Drinking water source protection - Watershed reforestation, riparian buffers Wastewater treatment - Constructed wetlands, aquatic plant systems Flood management - Retention ponds, green roofs, sponge city concepts Coastal resilience - Mangrove restoration protecting coastal SPAM infrastructure
Related Note: Outline_Daya_Dukung_Tampung_Pencemaran - Environmental carrying capacity and NbSGreen and Blue Finance:Verbatim (Indonesian): "didorong diversifikasi produk dan layanan yang sesuai dengan kebutuhan masyarakat dan perkembangan zaman, seperti pembiayaan perumahan, pembiayaan berkelanjutan (hijau dan biru)" Translation: "diversification of products and services according to community needs and contemporary developments is encouraged, such as housing financing, sustainable financing (green and blue)" Financial Instruments: Green bonds - For wastewater treatment, water-efficient technologies, watershed restoration Blue bonds - For coastal water supply, marine wastewater outfalls, desalination Land Value Capture - Capturing increased land values from infrastructure investment Blended finance - Combining public and private capital Financing Gap: Document notes need for Rp 6,445 trillion for infrastructure, with government providing only 37%, requiring 42% private sector investment.RPJMN 2025-2029 recognizes lakes as critical water resources requiring integrated management across environmental protection, economic development, and tourism sectors. Lake management is positioned within the blue economy framework, linking freshwater lake ecosystems to broader aquatic resource strategies.Source: KPU #22 (02.17.01) - Priority 2Verbatim (Indonesian): "Peningkatan pengelolaan kualitas air di sungai dan danau" Translation: "Improvement of water quality management in rivers and lakes" Program Components:Target Outcomes: Increased water quality data availability for rivers and lakes Improved surface water quality through systematic monitoring Enhanced environmental parameter testing capacity Strengthened water pollution control in industrial sectors Implementing Agencies (Multi-Ministerial Coordination): Ministry of Environment and Forestry / Environmental Management Agency Ministry of Public Works (water resource management) Ministry of Agriculture (agricultural runoff control) Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries (aquatic ecosystems) Ministry of Health (drinking water quality) Ministry of Higher Education, Science and Technology (research and monitoring) National Research and Innovation Agency National Food Agency Local Governments Funding Sources: State Budget (Belanja K/L) Regional Budget (APBD)
Regulatory Architecture Note: Lake water quality management links to existing drinking water quality standards and comprehensive water quality monitoring frameworks.Source: KPU #31 (03.05.08) - Priority 3Verbatim (Indonesian): "Percepatan pembangunan destinasi pariwisata prioritas Danau Toba" Translation: "Acceleration of Lake Toba priority tourism destination development" Strategic Positioning: Lake Toba is designated as one of Indonesia's 13 priority tourism destinations, receiving dedicated national priority activity (Kegiatan Prioritas) status. This elevates Lake Toba to the same strategic level as Borobudur-Yogyakarta-Prambanan, Lombok-Gili Tramena, and Labuan Bajo.Development Strategy: Lake Toba development follows integrated approach: Blue-Green-Circular Economy principles applied to lake ecosystem management Green infrastructure for sustainable tourism facilities Inclusive tourism value chains benefiting local communities Climate resilience and disaster preparedness for lake environments Environmental carrying capacity protection Institutional Framework: Badan Otorita Pariwisata (Tourism Authority Body) strengthened for Lake Toba Indonesia Quality Tourism Fund provides financing mechanism Multi-stakeholder coordination: national government, regional government, SOEs, private sector Funding Sources: State Budget (Belanja K/L) Regional Budget - Special Allocation Fund (DAK) Regional Budget (APBD) State-Owned Enterprises (BUMN) Private Sector Investment Related Context: Lake Toba is situated within broader Sumatera regional development strategy that identifies five strategic creative economy areas:Verbatim (Indonesian): "ekonomi kreatif yang tersebar di 5 kawasan, yaitu Dataran Tinggi Gayo-Danau Laut Tawar, Danau Toba, Dataran Tinggi Minangkabau, Candi Muarojambi, dan Belitung" Translation: "creative economy spread across 5 areas, namely Gayo Highlands-Lake Laut Tawar, Lake Toba, Minangkabau Highlands, Muarojambi Temple, and Belitung" This positions Lake Toba and Lake Laut Tawar as economic growth centers integrating cultural heritage, natural resource management, and sustainable tourism.Source: Priority 2 - Blue Economy IntegrationVerbatim (Indonesian): "pengembangan pariwisata bahari dan danau" Translation: "development of marine and lake tourism" Strategic Integration: Lakes are explicitly included in blue economy development alongside marine resources, recognizing: Freshwater fisheries as part of aquatic food systems Lake-based tourism comparable to marine tourism Ecosystem services from lake watersheds Water supply for agriculture and communities Climate regulation functions Blue Food Development: Lakes contribute to "Pangan Akuatik (Blue Food)" development strategy (KPU #7), which aims to: Diversify protein sources beyond terrestrial agriculture Develop sustainable freshwater aquaculture Integrate capture fisheries and aquaculture Reduce pressure on marine ecosystems by developing inland water resources Environmental Policy Context:Lakes are managed under integrated environmental quality improvement framework:Verbatim (Indonesian): "Peningkatan kualitas lingkungan hidup dan tata ruang dilakukan untuk memastikan ketersediaan daya dukung dan daya tampung lingkungan yang sejalan dengan pertumbuhan ekonomi" Translation: "Improvement of environmental quality and spatial planning is conducted to ensure availability of environmental carrying capacity and assimilative capacity in line with economic growth" Carrying Capacity Management: Daya dukung lingkungan (environmental carrying capacity) - Maximum development level lake ecosystems can sustain Daya tampung lingkungan (environmental assimilative capacity) - Maximum pollution load lakes can process without degradation Spatial planning integration to balance tourism/economic development with ecological protection
Related Note: Carrying capacity and pollution assimilative capacity framework provides technical methodology.Key Challenges: Eutrophication from agricultural runoff and urban wastewater discharge Sedimentation reducing water storage capacity and navigability Invasive species disrupting native lake ecosystems Tourism pressure on fragile lake environments Climate change altering lake hydrology and thermal stratification Multi-jurisdictional coordination (lakes often span multiple administrative boundaries) Integrated Management Opportunities: Payment for Ecosystem Services (PES) schemes where downstream beneficiaries fund upstream watershed conservation Community-based lake management involving local fishing communities and indigenous groups Real-time monitoring systems using IoT sensors for water quality Nature-based solutions including constructed wetlands for nutrient removal Integrated lake basin planning coordinating water allocation, tourism, conservation, and food production Connection to National Water Security: Lake management contributes to National Water Security Index targets (3.48 → 3.75) by: Serving as strategic water reserves during dry seasons Supporting agricultural irrigation systems Providing drinking water sources for surrounding communities Maintaining environmental flows for downstream ecosystems Source: Priority 8 - Environmental Harmony and Climate AdaptationVerbatim (Indonesian): "Pembangunan berketahanan iklim diimplementasikan untuk menyeimbangkan aspek ekonomi, sosial, dan lingkungan. Implementasi aksi pembangunan berketahanan iklim diterjemahkan sebagai tindakan yang mengurangi potensi kerugian ekonomi akibat ancaman bahaya, kerentanan, dampak, dan risiko perubahan iklim yang difokuskan pada empat sektor prioritas, yaitu sektor kelautan dan pesisir (ocean climate), air, pertanian, serta kesehatan." Translation: "Climate-resilient development is implemented to balance economic, social, and environmental aspects. Implementation of climate-resilient development actions is translated as actions that reduce potential economic losses due to hazard threats, vulnerability, impacts, and climate change risks focused on four priority sectors: ocean and coastal sector (ocean climate), water, agriculture, and health." Water as 1 of 4 Climate Priority Sectors - Recognizes water's critical vulnerability to climate change.Five Policy Directions for Climate Resilience:(a) Peningkatan ketahanan iklim pesisir dan laut (Ocean and coastal climate resilience enhancement)(b) Pengelolaan sumber daya air adaptif iklim (Climate-adaptive water resource management)(c) Pengembangan dan implementasi pertanian ramah iklim (Climate-smart agriculture development)(d) Pencegahan dan pengendalian penyakit sensitif iklim (Climate-sensitive disease prevention)(e) Penguatan tata kelola dan kapasitas untuk pembangunan berketahanan iklim (Climate resilience governance strengthening)National Targets:
Related Note: BAB_V_Kasus_1_Pencemaran_Air_Sungai - River water pollution case study (climate impacts)23 Million People at Risk by 2050:Verbatim (Indonesian): "Data dari Climate Central menyebutkan bahwa sekitar 23 juta penduduk pesisir di Indonesia diproyeksikan akan menghadapi banjir laut tahunan pada tahun 2050 akibat kenaikan muka air laut." Translation: "Data from Climate Central states that approximately 23 million coastal residents in Indonesia are projected to face annual sea flooding by 2050 due to sea level rise." Combined Threat: Sea level rise: +50 cm projected Land subsidence: 1-15 cm/year in Jakarta & Semarang Total relative rise: Up to 3.5 meters in worst-affected areas Vulnerable Administrative Units: 311 kabupaten/kota (regencies/cities) 1,643 kecamatan (sub-districts) 6,367 desa/kelurahan (villages) 30% of coastal villages already showing displacement signs (2013-2023) Water Infrastructure Implications: Saltwater intrusion into freshwater sources Coastal SPAM infrastructure flooding Groundwater contamination Need for giant sea wall and mangrove restoration Verbatim (Indonesian): "Di sisi lain, jumlah hari hujan cenderung menurun, sementara intensitas hujan lebih lebat dan ekstrem. Perubahan ini meningkatkan risiko banjir di daerah hilir saat kejadian hujan ekstrem serta memperpanjang periode kekeringan." Translation: "On the other hand, the number of rainy days tends to decrease, while rainfall intensity is heavier and more extreme. These changes increase flood risk in downstream areas during extreme rainfall events and prolong drought periods." Dual Crisis: Same regions face BOTH intensified flooding AND prolonged droughts Requires dual adaptation: flood control + drought mitigation infrastructure Traditional seasonal water management patterns disrupted Water Quality Program (KPU #22): "Peningkatan pengelolaan kualitas air di sungai dan danau" (Improvement of water quality management in rivers and lakes) Critical Need: Addressing 70% contamination rate in household water sources
Related Note: Water Quality Parameters -- Monitoring and Maintaining the Health of Our Waterways - Monitoring frameworksSource: Priority 6 - Building from Villages and from BelowVerbatim (Indonesian): "Secara agregat kualitas layanan dasar perdesaan masih timpang dibandingkan layanan dasar perkotaan, dengan data persentase desa dengan (i) akses air minum aman 18,9 persen; (ii) sanitasi aman 4,77 persen; (iii) layanan kesehatan 25,99 persen; (iv) rumah layak huni 24,62 persen." Translation: "In aggregate, the quality of basic services in rural areas is still unbalanced/imbalanced compared to urban basic services, with data showing the percentage of villages with (i) safe drinking water access at 18.9 percent; (ii) safe sanitation at 4.77 percent; (iii) health services at 25.99 percent; (iv) adequate housing at 24.62 percent." Catastrophic Rural WASH Statistics: Only 4.77% of villages have safe sanitation (95.23% lack access) Only 18.9% of villages have safe drinking water (81.1% lack access) Poor sanitation identified as primary cause of housing inadequacy
Related Note: Welcoming Remark for IsWASH2023 - WASH sector coordinationAffordable Housing with Good Sanitation - Quick Win Program:Verbatim (Indonesian): "Melanjutkan Pembangunan Infrastruktur Desa dan Kelurahan, Bantuan Langsung Tunai (BLT), dan Menjamin Penyediaan Rumah Murah Bersanitasi Baik untuk yang Membutuhkan, terutama Generasi Milenial, Generasi Z, dan Masyarakat Berpenghasilan Rendah (MBR)." Translation: "Continuing Village and Neighborhood Infrastructure Development, Direct Cash Assistance (BLT), and Ensuring Provision of Affordable Housing with Good Sanitation for Those in Need, especially Millennials, Generation Z, and Low-Income Communities (MBR)." Target Population: Masyarakat Berpenghasilan Rendah (MBR) - Low-Income Communities Generasi Milenial dan Generasi Z - Millennials and Generation Z Masyarakat Miskin dan Rentan - Poor and Vulnerable Communities Verbatim (Indonesian): "Penyediaan perumahan juga perlu dilengkapi dengan infrastruktur dasar permukiman (air minum aman, air limbah, persampahan, drainase lingkungan, dan lainnya)" Translation: "Housing provision also needs to be equipped with basic settlement infrastructure (safe drinking water, wastewater, solid waste, environmental drainage, and others)" Mandatory Components: All housing interventions MUST include complete WASH infrastructure.Poor Sanitation as Housing Inadequacy Factor: "aspek ketahanan bangunan dan kondisi sanitasi yang buruk menjadi faktor utama penyebab ketidaklayakan hunian tersebut." Translation: "building resilience aspects and poor sanitation conditions are the main factors causing housing inadequacy." Causal Chain: Poor sanitation → housing inadequacy → slum formation (77,000 hectares nationwide)Dana Desa (Village Fund) Prioritization:Verbatim (Indonesian): "pembinaan pemerintah desa tentang prioritas pemanfaatan Dana Desa yang digunakan untuk pemenuhan infrastruktur perdesaan" Translation: "guidance for village governments on priorities for utilizing Village Funds used for fulfilling rural infrastructure" Implementation Mechanisms: Dana Desa guidance - Village budgets directed toward water/sanitation infrastructure SEPAKAT system - Integrated data-based development planning for village-level targeting Klinik Rumah (Housing Clinics) - Technical assistance for self-build housing with sanitation Mikro Kredit - Micro credit schemes for incremental construction Village governments as primary stakeholders - Decentralized implementation 30 Priority Rural Development Areas (KPP):Verbatim (Indonesian): "pengembangan pusat pertumbuhan ekonomi lokal, pengembangan skala indikasi 30 Kawasan Perdesaan Prioritas (KPP), penguatan lembaga ekonomi desa" Translation: "development of local economic growth centers, development at the scale of 30 indicated Priority Rural Areas (KPP), strengthening of village economic institutions" Strategic Focus: 30 Priority Rural Areas receive concentrated infrastructure investment including water and sanitation.Rural-Urban Linkages: "Pendekatan ini menekankan keterkaitan desa-kota (rural-urban linkages)." Infrastructure must support rural-urban economic integration, not just household access.Verbatim (Indonesian): "pemenuhan 100 persen akses rumah tangga terhadap rumah yang dilengkapi dengan infrastruktur dasar permukiman (air minum aman, air limbah, dan persampahan) pada tahun 2045." Translation: "achieving 100 percent household access to housing equipped with basic settlement infrastructure (safe drinking water, wastewater, and solid waste) by 2045." Long-Term Vision: Universal WASH access in housing by 2045 as national commitment.Source: Chapter I - Development Evaluation and ChallengesTotal Water Resources: Surface water: 2,783.3 billion m³/year Groundwater potential: 20,903.3 billion m³/year Total potential: Over 23,686 billion m³/year Regional Distribution Crisis:Verbatim (Indonesian): "Wilayah padat penduduk seperti Pulau Jawa, yang menampung 56,1 persen populasi nasional, hanya memiliki 6,3 persen dari total ketersediaan air permukaan. Sebaliknya, wilayah-wilayah dengan sumber daya air melimpah seperti Papua (27,6 persen), Kalimantan (28,5 persen), dan Sumatera (26,1 persen) menampung populasi yang jauh lebih kecil." Translation: "Densely populated areas such as Java Island, which houses 56.1 percent of the national population, only has 6.3 percent of total surface water availability. Conversely, regions with abundant water resources such as Papua (27.6 percent), Kalimantan (28.5 percent), and Sumatera (26.1 percent) house far smaller populations." Water-Population Imbalance:Critical Finding: Java faces an 8.9x deficit in water availability per capita compared to national average.
Related Note: Water Conflict in Indonesia - Understanding Java's water allocation conflicts12.7 Million Hectares of Critical Land:Verbatim (Indonesian): "keberadaan hutan yang berfungsi sebagai pengatur tata air alami tertekan akibat tingginya pertumbuhan penduduk dan aktivitas ekonomi yang tidak berkelanjutan. Saat ini, 12,7 juta hektare lahan kritis sudah tidak berfungsi sebagai media pengatur tata air." Translation: "the existence of forests that function as natural water regulators is under pressure due to high population growth and unsustainable economic activities. Currently, 12.7 million hectares of critical land no longer function as water regulation media." Function Lost: Water infiltration and groundwater recharge Flood control and peak flow attenuation Dry season baseflow maintenance Erosion and sedimentation control Forest Cover Loss Projection: "tutupan hutan pada habitat spesies kunci di sebelah barat garis Wallacea akan menyusut dari 80,3 persen pada tahun 2000 menjadi 49,7 persen pada tahun 2045, terutama pada wilayah Sumatera dan Kalimantan." Translation: "forest cover in key species habitat west of the Wallace Line will shrink from 80.3 percent in 2000 to 49.7 percent in 2045, especially in Sumatra and Kalimantan regions." 30.6 percentage point forest cover loss projected in critical watersheds.
Related Note: Outline_Daya_Dukung_Tampung_Pencemaran - Environmental carrying capacity70% of Household Water Sources Contaminated:Verbatim (Indonesian): "Sekitar 70 persen dari 20 ribu sumber air minum rumah tangga yang diuji tercemar (Badan Pusat Statistik, 2022)." Translation: "Approximately 70 percent of 20 thousand household drinking water sources tested were contaminated (Statistics Indonesia, 2022)." Crisis Indicators: 70% contamination rate in 20,000 tested sources (2020-2022) Indonesia is highest-polluted country in Southeast Asia (WHO 2021) Systematic environmental degradation affecting water quality Related Notes:
Water Quality Parameters -- Monitoring and Maintaining the Health of Our Waterways - Parameters and monitoring
BAB_V_Kasus_1_Pencemaran_Air_Sungai - Citarum River pollution case study
Standar kualitas air minum - Drinking water quality standards Altered Precipitation Patterns: Fewer rainy days but more intense rainfall Increased flood risk in downstream areas during extreme events Prolonged drought periods between rainfall events Unpredictable seasonal patterns disrupting water management Hydrometeorological Disaster Trends: Increased frequency and intensity of floods, landslides, droughts Zero provinces classified as low disaster risk 168 kabupaten/kota in high disaster risk category 346 kabupaten/kota in medium disaster risk category Infrastructure Progress: Irrigation system development supporting agricultural productivity Clean water and sanitation access expansion contributing to poverty reduction Drainage infrastructure development in rural areas Program Kali Bersih (Clean River Program) improving Environmental Quality Index Conservation Achievements: 51.14 million hectares terrestrial protected areas (26.85% of land) 29.9 million hectares marine conservation areas (9.2% of territorial waters) 665,049.5 hectares increase in marine conservation during RPJMN 2020-2024 Priority 2: Swasembada Air (Water Self-Sufficiency) - FEW Nexus framework Priority 3: Water infrastructure development (SPAM, sanitation, dams) Priority 4: Human development - health outcomes from WASH access Priority 6: Rural water and village development - affordable housing with sanitation Priority 8: Climate-resilient water management - adaptation and environmental qualityRegional Spatial Targeting:Verbatim (Indonesian): "pengembangan kawasan swasembada pangan, air, energi, dan kawasan komoditas unggulan." Translation: "development of food, water, energy self-sufficiency zones, and priority commodity zones." Regional Distribution: Java: 11 swasembada water zones Sumatra: Multiple zones (strategic role for food-water-energy) Kalimantan: Multiple zones Sulawesi: Multiple zones Integrated Development: Water self-sufficiency zones integrate food production, energy generation, and water security in spatial planning.Water-Food Linkages: Water storage for agriculture, livestock, irrigation Agricultural water needs in river basin water accounting Water scarcity as limiting factor for food production Water-Energy Linkages: Hydropower from water storage (105 built dams) Water for biofuel production and renewable energy Energy for water pumping, treatment, distribution Water-Blue Economy Linkages: Coastal water quality management Freshwater-seawater interface management Aquaculture water needs Marine ecosystem health (Seawater Quality Index) SDG 6 Targets and RPJMN Alignment:Overall SDG 6 Alignment: Moderate-to-Strong, but targets less ambitious than universal access goals.Six Governance Pillars for Water and Sanitation:Verbatim (Indonesian): "tata kelola yang mencakup perencanaan yang terpadu, penguatan fungsi dan kelembagaan regulator, pengelolaan aset yang terintegrasi, penetapan dan penerapan tarif/retribusi yang adil dan transparan, operasionalisasi yang efisien, serta jaminan enabling environment lainnya." Translation: "governance that includes integrated planning, strengthening regulatory function and institutions, integrated asset management, setting and applying fair and transparent tariffs/levies, efficient operationalization, and guarantees of other enabling environments." Six Pillars: Integrated planning Strengthened regulatory institutions (Badan Regulator) Integrated asset management Fair and transparent tariff setting Efficient operations Enabling environment guarantees Two Acceleration Programs: Program Percepatan Penyediaan Air Minum (Drinking Water Provision Acceleration Program) Program Percepatan Pembangunan Sanitasi Permukiman (Settlement Sanitation Development Acceleration Program) Financing Mechanism: Land Value Capture (LVC) explicitly mentioned as innovative financing approach.International Best Practice Adoption:Verbatim (Indonesian): "penyediaan dan pengawasan sanitasi aman, berkelanjutan, dan berketahanan iklim berbasis Citi-Wide Inclusive Sanitation" CWIS Principles: Citywide coverage - Not just networked areas, entire urban area Inclusive approach - Prioritizing low-income and informal settlements Service-oriented - Focus on sanitation outcomes, not just infrastructure Integrated solutions - Combining on-site (septic) and off-site (sewerage) Climate resilience - Adaptation to flooding, drought, sea-level rise
Related Note: Singkatan dan Akronim terkait Air Minum, Sanitasi, dan Hygiene - CWIS and WASH terminologyPrimary Agency: Kementerian Pekerjaan Umum dan Perumahan Rakyat (Ministry of Public Works and Public Housing) - All dam projects, SPAM systems, infrastructure construction Supporting Agencies: Kementerian Lingkungan Hidup dan Kehutanan - Water quality, watershed management Badan Pengelola Dana Lingkungan Hidup - Climate finance for water projects Provincial/Local Governments - SPAM operations, sanitation service delivery New: Badan Regulator Air Minum dan Sanitasi - Regulatory oversight Financing Structure (National Infrastructure): Government (37%) - National and local budget (APBN, APBD) State-Owned Enterprises (21%) - BUMN infrastructure investment Private Sector (42%) - Investment and PPPs (largest share) International Partners - Climate finance, development banks Total Need: Rp 6,445 trillion for infrastructure (2025-2029)Innovative Mechanisms: Green bonds and blue bonds Islamic finance (sukuk) Blended finance Public-Private Partnerships (PPP) Land Value Capture (LVC) Data and Transparency Systems: Benchmarking system for service performance (Badan Regulator function) Public reporting mechanisms Water accounting at river basin level Smart water management data platforms SEPAKAT system for village-level targeting Integrated Social-Economic Registration System (Sistem Registrasi Sosial Ekonomi) No New Regulations Needed for Priority 3:Verbatim (Indonesian): "Kerangka Regulasi eksisting untuk memfasilitasi pelaksanaan Prioritas Nasional 3 dinilai telah memadai sehingga tidak ada kerangka regulasi yang diusulkan." Translation: "The existing Regulatory Framework to facilitate the implementation of National Priority 3 is considered adequate so that no regulatory framework is proposed." Existing Legal Framework: UU No. 17/2019 - Water Resources Law UU No. 1/2011 - Housing and Settlement Areas Law PP on Drinking Water Supply Systems (various implementing regulations) PP on Wastewater Management (various implementing regulations) Permenkes No. 2/2023 - Environmental Health Regulation implementing PP 66/2014 Related Notes:
Peraturan Menteri Kesehatan Nomor 2 Tahun 2023 tentang Kesehatan Lingkungan - Health ministry water regulations
RPS_Hukum_Lingkungan_2025 - Environmental law curriculum covering water regulations Related to Water Conflict Resolution:The Constitutional Court of Indonesia established 6 Basic Principles for water conflict resolution (referenced in existing notes): Right to water as human right State control and public welfare orientation Sustainable and integrated water resource management Priority for basic needs Conservation and protection Participatory management Related Notes:
Kekuatan dan Keterbatasan dari '6 Prinsip Dasar' Mahkamah Konstitusi Indonesia dalam Menyelesaikan Konflik Air - Analysis of principles and limitations
Water Conflict in Indonesia - Application to real conflicts Water Resources vs. Water Services:Two distinct regulatory frameworks exist (as documented in existing vault notes):Water Resource Regulation: Allocation policies and permits Conservation and protection Quality standards for water bodies Groundwater regulation Inter-basin transfers Water Service Regulation: Drinking water quality standards Testing and monitoring procedures Source protection zones Customer rights and service standards Tariff regulation Complaint handling mechanisms Environmental responsibility New Integration: The Badan Regulator Air Minum dan Sanitasi bridges these frameworks by covering raw water → drinking water → wastewater in integrated manner.
Related Note: Perbedaan Fitur Regulasi Sumber Daya Air dengan Pelayanan Air - Distinguishing the two frameworksCarrying Capacity and Absorption Capacity:Legal Basis: UU 32/2009 - Environmental Protection and Management Law PP 22/2021 - Environmental Protection and Management Implementation Key Concepts (from vault notes): Daya Dukung Lingkungan (Environmental Carrying Capacity) - Maximum pressure environment can sustain Daya Tampung Pencemaran Air (Water Pollution Absorption Capacity) - Maximum pollution load water body can absorb Baku Mutu (Quality Standards) - Regulatory limits for pollutants Application: River and lake water quality management (KPU #22) Industrial wastewater discharge standards Drinking water quality standards Seawater quality protection Related Notes:
Outline_Daya_Dukung_Tampung_Pencemaran - Carrying capacity concepts and legal framework
BAB_V_Kasus_1_Pencemaran_Air_Sungai - Citarum River case study applying these concepts Rencana Pengamanan Air (Water Safety Plan):Terminology and framework documented in vault (bilingual Indonesian-English): Compliance monitoring Control measures Hazard identification Critical limits Corrective actions Risk management protocols
Related Note: Terminologi terkait Rencana Pengamanan Air - Comprehensive water safety terminologyMulti-Stakeholder WASH Coordination: BAPPENAS (National Planning Agency) - Overall coordination Jejaring AMPL (WASH Network) - Civil society coordination Academic institutions - Research and capacity building Development partners - Technical and financial support Coordination Platform: Indonesian WASH Symposium (IsWASH) - annual knowledge exchange
Related Note: Welcoming Remark for IsWASH2023 - WASH sector coordination frameworkBased on comprehensive analysis of RPJMN 2025-2029 water content:1. Accelerate Regulatory Body Operationalization Priority: Establish Badan Regulator Air Minum dan Sanitasi by 2026 to enable ambitious 2029 targets Action: Recruit technical staff, establish benchmarking systems, develop tariff methodology Critical: Ensure operational and financial independence as designed 2. Address Rural-Urban Disparities Crisis: 95.23% of villages lack safe sanitation, 81.1% lack safe drinking water Action: Prioritize Dana Desa allocations to water/sanitation through SEPAKAT system Target: Achieve at least 50% rural village coverage by 2029 (from 4.77% and 18.9%) 3. Implement Java Water Rebalancing Challenge: 56.1% population with only 6.3% water (8.9x deficit) Options: Inter-basin transfers, demand management, regional development rebalancing Urgent: Prevent water conflicts through equitable allocation frameworks 4. Scale Watershed Restoration Crisis: 12.7 million hectares no longer function as water regulators Action: Massive reforestation and rehabilitation program Target: Halt further degradation, restore 30% by 2029 5. Mobilize Climate Finance Need: 42% private sector financing (Rp 2,707 trillion) required Mechanism: Green bonds, blue bonds, blended finance Focus: Climate-resilient infrastructure (CWIS, coastal protection, NbS) 6. Water Quality Emergency Response Crisis: 70% of water sources contaminated Action: Accelerate river/lake quality management (KPU #22) Target: Achieve Water Quality Index of 72.77 by 2029 (from 54.59) 7. Coastal Adaptation at Scale Threat: 23 million people facing annual flooding by 2050 Action: Implement 311 vulnerable kabupaten/kota adaptation plans Infrastructure: Complete giant sea wall, restore 3.36M ha mangroves 8. Operationalize FEW Nexus Framework: Food-Energy-Water Nexus is well-articulated Gap: Need integrated indicators and planning tools Action: Develop composite FEW Nexus Index for holistic monitoring 9. Leverage Existing Knowledge Asset: 16 highly relevant existing notes in your vault covering water conflict, regulations, quality standards, case studies Action: Create rich internal link network for knowledge integration Platform: Use digital garden to make RPJMN water analysis accessible 10. Multi-Stakeholder Coordination Mechanism: Strengthen BAPPENAS-Jejaring AMPL-academic partnerships Platform: Expand IsWASH symposium to include RPJMN implementation monitoring Data: Implement transparent public reporting through Badan Regulator Achieving RPJMN 2025-2029 water targets requires: Political Will - Sustained commitment beyond 2025 election transition Financing - Mobilizing Rp 2,707 trillion private sector investment Institutional Capacity - Building competent Badan Regulator and local operators Technology Adoption - Smart water management, CWIS, water accounting Governance Reforms - Multi-level coordination (central-provincial-local) Climate Adaptation - Mainstreaming resilience across all water investments Equity Focus - Prioritizing underserved rural populations and vulnerable groups Data and Transparency - Evidence-based decision making and public accountability Implementation Risks: Financing gap - Achieving 42% private sector share uncertain Capacity constraints - Limited local government technical capacity for O&M Coordination challenges - Multi-level governance requires sustained coordination Climate uncertainty - Extreme weather may exceed infrastructure design parameters Political transitions - 2025 elections may disrupt program continuity Urban bias - Strategic projects concentrated in Java/Sumatra may neglect remote areas Mitigation Strategies: Early operationalization of Badan Regulator to institutionalize reforms Phased implementation with quick wins to build momentum Robust monitoring and adaptive management Climate-resilient design standards for all infrastructure Multi-stakeholder oversight to ensure accountability RPJMN 2025-2029 presents Indonesia's most comprehensive water sector strategy to date, elevating water from a technical sector to a national self-sufficiency priority alongside food and energy. The plan integrates eight key dimensions: Strategic elevation - Water as "fondasi kehidupan berkelanjutan" Institutional reform - Independent regulatory body with full value chain coverage FEW Nexus integration - Holistic food-energy-water planning Climate resilience - Water as 1 of 4 climate priority sectors Infrastructure acceleration - 114% increase in piped water, 194% in sanitation Quality improvement - 33% increase in Water Quality Index Rural equity - "Rumah Murah Bersanitasi Baik" as national quick-win Source-to-sea integration - Upstream watershed to coastal protection The Most Transformative Element: Establishment of Badan Regulator Air Minum dan Sanitasi (Water and Sanitation Regulatory Body) with operational and financial independence represents a fundamental governance reform that can break decades of fragmented authority and enable the ambitious targets set forth.The Most Urgent Challenge: Addressing the rural WASH crisis where only 4.77% of villages have safe sanitation and 18.9% have safe water requires immediate, massive mobilization of resources through Dana Desa and multi-level coordination.The Most Critical Success Factor: Mobilizing 42% private sector financing (Rp 2,707 trillion) through green/blue bonds and innovative mechanisms like Land Value Capture will determine whether infrastructure targets can be achieved.The Most Significant Risk: Climate change impacts (23 million facing annual flooding by 2050, altered precipitation, 12.7M ha degraded watersheds) may overwhelm adaptive capacity if infrastructure is not designed for resilience from the outset.The Path Forward: Indonesia has articulated a comprehensive, integrated vision for water security. Success depends on translating this vision into funded annual work plans, building institutional capacity, maintaining political commitment, and ensuring no one is left behind—particularly the 95% of rural villages currently without safe sanitation.
Full glossary available in: Singkatan dan Akronim terkait Air Minum, Sanitasi, dan HygienePrimary RPJMN Documents Analyzed: III_Prioritas_2_Memantapkan_Sistem_Pertahanan_Keamanan.md - Priority 2: Water Self-Sufficiency & FEW Nexus III_Prioritas_3_Melanjutkan_Pengembangan_Infrastruktur_dan.md - Priority 3: Water Infrastructure III_Prioritas_6_Membangun_dari_Desa_dan_dari_Bawah_untuk.md - Priority 6: Rural Water & Village Development III_Prioritas_8_Memperkuat_Penyelarasan_Kehidupan_yang.md - Priority 8: Climate-Resilient Water Management I_Evaluasi_dan_Tantangan_Pembangunan.md - Chapter I: Water Resources Baseline & Challenges II_Kebijakan_Pembangunan.md - Chapter II: Development Policy (KPU list) Supporting Documents in Vault: 16 water-related notes covering governance, quality standards, case studies, legal frameworks Baseline Conditions (2024): National Water Security Index: 3.48 Urban piped water access: 24% Safe sanitation access: 10.21% Water Quality Index: 54.59 Rural safe water access: 18.9% of villages Rural safe sanitation: 4.77% of villages Contaminated water sources: 70% Degraded watersheds: 12.7 million hectares Targets (2029): National Water Security Index: 3.75 Urban piped water access: 51.36% Safe sanitation access: 30% Water Quality Index: 72.77 Adequate housing: 74% Infrastructure Projects: 4 new dams (Maluku, NTT, Gorontalo, Central Java) 2 regional SPAM systems 1 giant sea wall (North Java coast) 30 Priority Rural Development Areas Vulnerable Populations: 23 million coastal residents facing annual flooding by 2050 311 kabupaten/kota vulnerable to climate displacement 6,367 villages at risk from sea level rise 56.1% of population (Java) with 6.3% of water resources Water Governance & Conflict:
Water Conflict in Indonesia

Singkatan dan Akronim terkait Air Minum, Sanitasi, dan Hygiene Title: Indonesia's Water Sector Strategy in RPJMN 2025-2029: A Comprehensive Analysis Author: Mohamad Mova AlAfghani Methodology: Claude Multi-Agent Orchestration (6 parallel specialized agents) Date: October 29, 2025 Version: 1.0 Word Count: ~15,000 words Source Authority: RPJMN 2025-2029 (National Medium-Term Development Plan) File Location: D:\Obsidian\obsidianpublish\rpjmn\RPJMN_Water_Comprehensive_Analysis.md Status: Ready for Publication License: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International Contact: [Your contact information]
Tags: #rpjmn #water-security #swasembada-air #few-nexus #water-infrastructure #cwis #climate-resilience #rural-water #badan-regulator #wash #indonesia #policy-analysis
Related: README | 00_INDEX | LINKING_STRATEGYThis document represents a comprehensive synthesis of Indonesia's water sector strategy as articulated in RPJMN 2025-2029, integrating analysis across multiple national priorities with rich contextual linking to existing knowledge resources. It is designed for policymakers, researchers, development partners, and civil society organizations engaged in Indonesia's water sector.

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar
